title: Plaintiffs take one for the class actions team
text:
After wading through the 386-page judgment, Herbert Smith Freehills partner Jason Betts offered that while the court had decided a market-based theory of causation was appropriate, shareholders might still have to "prove they would not have purchased shares, or only at a lower price, if the true position had been known".

"Even if Myer had corrected the market, it would not have moved the share price ... so, while this is an important finding of continuous disclosure breach, it may not result in any damages being recovered by shareholders."

The judge even agreed that Myer could have cut costs to protect profit and said there were reasonable grounds for the views expressed, including the detailed budgeting process used to arrive at the expected net profit after tax that was considered and approved by the board.

Justice Beach clearly wants the case to settle, having said he will hear further from the parties as to damages. Still, it's hardly looking like a bonanza for the plaintiffs.

Plaintiff lawyer Damien Scattini, a partner at Quinn Emanuel, says there is no reason for Myer to appeal.

"They won. The applicant may appeal, and then Myer could cross-appeal to say that His Honour got it wrong about market-based causation.

"I can’t see the Full Court overturning the decision, which would leave someone throwing the dice in the High Court. My guess: market-based causation is here to stay."

Advertisement

Not having to prove individual reliance or loss is a big plus for plaintiffs, given that Beach is saying courts will accept market-based causation as a way to measure loss.

However Clyde & Co partner Janette McLennan says expert evidence on loss and quantum "will continue to be a central battleground on which these cases are fought beyond the threshold-liability questions".

"They are whether there was any information that was material to investors that was not disclosed to the market, and if there was whether any exceptions to disclosure under the listing rules apply."

It looks very much like the plaintiff in this case has taken one for the class actions team. The case wasn't good enough to get over the line, but next time it might be very different.
description: The big takeaway from the case is that market-based causation is alive and well. That's the bit that encouraged the litigation funders on Thursday, even if Justice Beach didn't lay down strict markers.
